column1: CJ 2.0 or CJ Elleby
It depends if you mean players overall or players who should actually get minutes at the NBA level. CJ Elleby is technically on our team, but the thought of relying on him is terrifying.

>the Blazers are definitely dealing w more injuries  I don't care who you think should start, only replying to the quoted bit -- and that's not true.  Blazers have played 17 games thus far, and every one of their rotation players played at least 12/17 games (70.5%). CJ played 13/17 (76.5%). The only ones playing fewer than 12 games were Little, Elleby and Blevins -- not rotational players -- and Collins who's been out since before the season started.  Mavs have played 18 games thus far, and 4 players in the expected 8-man rotation have played 9 or fewer games (that's 50% or less). The 8-man rotation have missed a combined 60 (that is 41.7%) of available games.

It's Game 4 of the NBA Finals. Dame has valiantly led an 8-man Blazers squad of Melo, Ant, Nas, Giles, Kanter, Elleby, and Hood to this point, but they simply don't have the firepower to take on the Nets star trio of KD, Kyrie, and Harden, as the Blazers are currently down 0-3 in the series. Kanter is even questionable for Game 4 after breaking his Ramadan fast with 77 McDonald's cheeseburgers.   The Rose Garden goes dark for player introductions, when faintly over the arena speakers you hear CJ say...   "On your left."   ...   ...   ...  Nets in 5

Yes players can improve.  That doesn't mean they will.  My whole point was it feels like Elleby peaked in his first real game, and I predict he'll be out of the NBA soon.   Calling someone's floor a 10th man means garbage time.  Almost no team runs 10 man rotations, especially after the early season games where teams sort out who get minutes.   Elleby frankly has no floor, as he has never played a minute outside garbage time save that one game.  We were also missing 4 starters (Dame, CJ, DJJ, Nurkic) and two other pieces in Collins and Little in order for him to get those 31 minutes, which was the 6th most for our team that game.

So mine doesn't fulfill the requirements.  I didn't think he'd be a star, and he isn't out of the league yet.   CJ Elleby.   After we drafted him last season, he didn't get an opportunity until disaster struck and we were missing 4 starters and like 3 bench pieces for a game against the 1-seeded 76ers.  Elleby was basically the reason we won that game in a massive upset, despite Embiid putting up gaudy numbers.   That was his first opportunity for minutes, and he showed up big time.   The hype went into full effect.   Us Blazers fans thought Olshey had done it again, continuing a trend of good 2nd round picks.    He has not looked good since.  While we will probably ride out the season since his contract is guaranteed, many have called to cut him to sign a training camp player such as Marquis Chriss.  It was a short lived hype, but Elleby's first game with minutes may end up being the best of a short-lived NBA career.   All that said, I'd be ecstatic to be proven wrong and for Elleby to become a rotation quality player for us.

I don't think either team does this, but Zach Collins+ CJ Elleby for PJ Tucker, straight up.    I would rather have Collins if he were healthy, but he's missed a lot of time recently.  I don't think he will be in rhythm or have chemistry come playoff time, and he needs a new contract next year, both for which are detrimental for a 'contending' team in Portland.  Tucker is very reliable and a strong vet.  He provides defense and 3pt shooting, which would be a great complement for our back court.    Elleby is an unknown.  In a couple of games, he's shown potential, especially that 76er game where we had only 1 starter and 6 missing players total.  But, one game isn't enough to give him high value.  I would think the Blazers would be higher on him than any other team.  Still, I think Rockets could be smart to take a swing on Collins.  Worst case, he's expiring.  Best case, he has a lot of potential.  You could argue he overlaps with Wood, but I think they could coexist.    I would be sad to see Z. Collins leave and not fulfill his potential here.  But, if we do not have him involved in a bigger trade deal before the deadline, I'd like to see him swapped with Tucker

Most of these guys are low value projects turned into solid role players and low end starters. Pretty good draft resume for not having a top 8 pick since Damian Lillard

They're a team that needs a rebuild or at least a retool but won't. As long as Neil Olshey is in charge they'll be the perennial solid playoff team that won't do anything in the playoffs unless the draw is exactly perfect like in 2019, similar to the Pacers of the West. Olshey is perfectly content just being a middle of the road team. Stotts isn't good but if they lose to the Nuggets he'll likely get way too much of the blame that Olshey should be getting. Don't know how anyone can hope to craft even a top 25 NBA defense starting three players 6' 3" or smaller and having your two main reserves be Melo and Kanter.   They won't trade Dame but could get a solid wing for CJ which is their biggest need and could maybe a fleece a guard needy team into getting something decent for Simons if they decided to deal him. Need to invest in more young guys like Nas Little or Elleby instead of signing subpar veterans like DJJ or Kanter. They're best draft pick since CJ was Gary Trent and he's not even on the team anymore. Hard to get good players when you're drafting so low every year but they've consistently missed on guys.   Hard to attract free agents to Portland but this team clearly needs a retool even if they beat Denver but I'd be surprised if the front office did anything.

Let me just go down the roster. There's a lot of unknowns.   Dame - definitely staying  CJ - if we make it out of the first round, I'd say he's definitely staying. If we lose in the first round, who knows. Total wildcard  Norm - another total wildcard. Will he want to stay somewhere he's the 3rd best guard? If he does, how much are we willing to pay a 3rd 6'3 guard who we'll have to play at SF? Repeater tax is an issue as well  RoCo - definitely staying  Nurk - definitely staying  Melo - likely upto him if he wants to play another season. I don't see us not signing him if he wants to come back  DJJ - has a PO for 10mil so he could leave for a bigger role, but idk how much money he'll find. I think he stays  Anfernee Simons - definitely staying (unless we put him in a package for a big trade)  Enes Kanter - likely gonna re-sign him, but definitely possible that we let him walk  RHJ - unless he gets a better offer from somewhere else, I think we'd keep him on a min  Nassir Little - definitely staying (unless we put him in a package for a big trade)  Harry Giles - probably going somewhere else where he'll either get more than a minimum or will get more mins  Zach Collins - another wildcard. How do you come to a fair contract value with someone who essentially hasn't played in 2 years. Gun to my head, we re-sign him even if it's just the QO  CJ Elleby - staying
